proposals.reasoning: This fits the low-drama pairs several people have already floated, keeps at least one active voice on the mission without stacking multiple central influencers together, and uses Frank as the common denominator many of you were comfortable with. I’m fine treating the result as light info rather than a hard clear or condemn on either of us so we don’t overreact to a single early outcome.

votes.comment: This is a broadly supported, low-drama pair for Quest 1 and we shouldn’t overcomplicate the opener.
Keeps both known evils off the mission and aligns with the low-drama consensus for Quest 1
Solid low-drama opener with one of my preferred anchors (Bob or Diana) plus Frank; Mission 1 is low info anyway, and this pairing is consistent with the consensus setup.
Consistent with my earlier support for Bob+Frank as a low-drama info grab; I’m fine treating the result as light info either way.
This matches the low-drama pairs I suggested earlier (Bob + Frank or Bob + me), so I’ll stay consistent and treat this as a light-info first probe.
Early Q1 with me on it and no strong red flags; good to get some light info without overreading the result.
Consistent with my suggested low-drama Frank pair; fine for light info without over-centering any one voice yet.

discussion.content: Early on I’d rather avoid stacking the first team with the loudest voices, so I’m okay with something like me plus one of Bob/Frank for a low-drama test run.
I’d rather not auto-lock Alice onto Mission 1 just because she spoke first—I'd be happier with something like Bob + Frank or Bob + Eve as a low-info, low-drama starting pair.

I’d like at least one of Bob or Diana on the first team so we get an early read on someone who’s been reliably logical in past games, but I’d avoid putting both of them together right away. Bob + Frank or Diana + Frank both feel like solid, low-drama options to me.

I like the idea of mixing one “talky” and one quieter player, so something like Diana + Frank or Bob + Frank works for me as a low-key first probe. I’d rather not auto-include Alice just because she opened the discussion.

I’d rather not overthink Quest 1, so I’m fine with something like Bob + Frank or Bob + me as a low-key info grab. I’d avoid pairing two of the more central voices together right away so we don’t blow too much trust equity on a blind stab.

I’m good being the “common denominator” here, and out of the pairs mentioned I slightly prefer Frank + Diana over Frank + Bob just so we’re not auto-centering Bob this early. If we do go Frank + Bob, I’d want us to treat a success/fail there as only very light info, not a hard clear or condemn.

I’m fine using Frank as the common piece, but I slightly prefer pairing him with Diana over Bob or Alice so we’re not funneling too much early influence through the same loud voices. If we really want a Bob read right away, then Bob + Frank is okay as long as we all agree a single fail there doesn’t auto-clear/condemn either of them.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s clean Bob–Frank result is our best concrete info, so keeping that core is standard. Adding a new, untested player gives us real information, and the table already converged on trying Eve here rather than immediately defaulting to Diana. If this mission succeeds, we have a strong three-player base for Mission 3; if it fails, we narrow evil to at most one of Bob/Frank plus Eve instead of spreading suspicion randomly.

votes.comment: Sticking with the clean Bob–Frank core plus adding a new player is standard and gives useful info either way, so I’m fine approving this.
Clean 2p core plus a single new test is standard here; with Alice and Diana off, odds are decent this stays good and gives strong info for Mission 3.
Clean 2p core plus adding one new player is standard for Mission 2, and broad table agreement plus the info gain makes this a good approve.
As evil I want Eve on the mission and the trusted Bob–Frank core preserved so we can sabotage while keeping suspicion diffuse.
This follows the clean 2p core from Mission 1 and adds new info with a single new player, which is the most standard and informative choice for Mission 2.
Clean 2p core with me and Bob is our best info; adding Eve is the standard informative test for Mission 2.
Standard to extend a clean 2-player core to 3; we need info, and this is the least arbitrary test right now.

discussion.content: Given the clean 2-person start, I’m inclined to keep trusting Bob and Frank for now, but I’d like to add someone who hasn’t been tested yet—maybe Diana or Eve—to actually learn something from this mission.

I’m happy to rerun with Frank and add one new person, and I slightly prefer trying Eve here over Diana just so we’re not immediately defaulting to the first suggestion. If this stays clean, we’ll have a solid core to build around for Mission 3.

Bob–Frank as a core makes sense after a clean 2p, but I’d like to see either Diana or Eve tested here—slight preference for Eve this round so we don’t leave all the untested players clustered together later.

I’m fine with Bob–Frank–Eve here since a clean 2p start is usually worth leaning into, but we should remember a single success doesn’t hard-clear anyone long term. Testing Eve now gives us info while keeping the core that just worked.
Bob–Frank–Eve sounds good to me too: we keep the proven pair and actually get some info on a new player. If this comes back clean, that’s a really strong base for Mission 3.
Sticking with Bob–me plus adding Eve seems like the best info play right now, as long as we all remember that even a clean 3p isn’t a permanent lock-clear on anyone. I’d approve Bob–Frank–Eve here.

I’m okay approving Bob–Frank–Eve here since rolling forward a clean 2p core is standard, but if this one fails I want us to be ready to seriously re-examine Bob/Frank rather than just auto-blaming the new add.

proposals.reasoning: This follows the table’s preferred structure of exactly one from {Bob, Frank, Eve} plus two from outside that pool. Bob is the mild consensus choice from that trio, and pairing him with Alice and me gives two completely new players to mission history while still keeping one person with prior mission experience. This should generate clear information without over-committing again to the full Mission 2 core, and it fits the repeatedly suggested pattern of Bob + two from {Alice, Grace, Diana}.

votes.comment: Fits the widely supported structure of exactly one from {Bob, Frank, Eve} plus two new players, and rejecting here would go against the emerging consensus without a strong alternative.

I like the 1-from-{Bob,Frank,Eve} structure, but putting both Alice and Diana together with Bob feels too high-variance; I’d rather see one of them swapped for Grace or Charlie to spread risk and get cleaner info.
Fits the consensus structure of exactly one from {Bob, Frank, Eve}; this tests Bob with two fresh players and avoids reusing the risky M2 core.
Team matches the consensus structure I advocated (Bob + 2 from {Alice, Grace, me}) and gives good info with only one player from the M2 fail pool.
Fits the ‘one of {Bob, Frank, Eve} plus two outsiders’ structure I supported, and this lineup should give useful info while not overcommitting to the M2 core.

Team fits the agreed structure of exactly one from {Bob, Frank, Eve} plus two new players; while I’m uneasy about how comfortably Bob is being centered, this still gives useful info without reusing the risky M2 core.
Team fits the agreed structure (exactly one of {Bob, Frank, Eve} plus two outside) and isn’t suspicious enough to justify burning a proposal, even though I’d slightly prefer a version including me.

discussion.content: Given the clean M1 and the single fail on M2, I think at least one of Bob/Frank/Eve has to sit out this round, and I’d prefer we don’t auto-clear Bob just because he was on the first success. I’d like a team something like 2 people from outside that trio plus one of them, so we’re not putting all our eggs in the same basket again.

I’d lean toward keeping at least two of the M2 players off for now and re-using just one, probably Bob, alongside two from {Charlie, Grace} so we get cleaner info without repeating the same risky core.

I’m fine with not auto-clearing anyone from M2, but I’d still like exactly one of {Bob, Frank, Eve} on this next team plus two from {Alice, Grace, Diana}, so we get fresh info without fully abandoning the earlier pool.

I like the “exactly one from {Bob, Frank, Eve}” idea, but I’d lean Bob over Frank/Eve for now and pair him with two from {Alice, Grace, me} so we get both new info and at least one person with mission history.

I’m on board with the “exactly one of {Bob, Frank, Eve}” approach, and from that pool I’d slightly prefer Bob, paired with two from {Alice, Grace, Diana}—something like Bob/Alice/Grace feels like a good balance of info and lower risk.

I agree we should stick to exactly one of {Bob, Frank, Eve}, but I’m not comfortable with how quickly everyone’s defaulting to Bob—something like Alice/Grace plus either me or Bob feels safer than auto-centering him again.

I like the “exactly one of {Bob, Frank, Eve}” structure, but I don’t love how fast the table’s anchoring on Bob specifically—that feels a bit too comfortable. I’d be happiest with something like Alice/Grace/Bob or Alice/Grace/Frank so we’re testing the M2 pool without tunneling on a single narrative.

proposals.reasoning: This team hard-benches both Bob and Diana, who were together on the double-fail Mission 3 and with Bob also on the earlier fail in Mission 2, making them the highest-risk pair right now. Between Alice and me, Alice feels hotter after being on the double-fail, and several of you (Charlie, Diana, Frank, Grace, and I) have independently converged on Charlie/Frank/Grace as a solid core and Eve over Alice as the fourth. This lineup maximizes using players who haven’t been paired in the failing configurations, follows the emerging table consensus, and gives us the cleanest new information while avoiding the scariest prior combinations.

votes.comment: If the three evils are Bob, Alice, and Diana, this team is entirely good; benching all three of them makes this lineup too likely to succeed.
Mission 2’s fail came from the Frank/Eve/Bob trio, so putting both Frank and Eve together again feels too risky; I’d rather see at most one of them on this team.

From the mission patterns, Bob must be good (likely Merlin), which forces both Alice and Diana as evil and at least one of Frank/Eve as the third evil from Mission 2. Since this team includes both Frank and Eve, it is guaranteed to contain at least one evil and is too risky at 2–1 down.
Eve (evil) is on the team while I’m safely benched, and it continues to frame the Bob/Diana block as the main suspicion, giving us a strong shot to secure the third fail.
I’m on the team, it matches the broad table consensus to bench Bob and Diana, and approving gives us a strong chance to close the game with a fail here.

Given Mission 2 and 3, if Bob is evil then at least one of Alice/Diana and exactly one of Charlie/Grace/Eve are also evil. This team includes all of Charlie/Grace/Eve, so it is guaranteed to contain at least one evil from my perspective and can’t be a safe pick.

Given all consistent role distributions, this team can contain at most one evil (often zero), while any team including Bob, Diana, or Alice risks 2+ evils. This is our safest shot at a must-succeed mission.

proposals.reasoning: We must bench the highest-risk pair: Bob and Diana. Bob is on both failing missions (2 and 3), making him the most likely common denominator for evil. Mission 3’s double fail (Bob, Alice, Diana) implies at least two evils among them, which raises Alice’s risk compared to Eve, who is only tied to the single-fail Mission 2 with Bob. I know I’m good, so the cleanest, least-linked block to prior fails is Charlie + Frank + Grace + Eve, which also matches the strongest table consensus for a Bob/Diana bench while preferring Eve over the hotter-read Alice.

votes.comment: I still don’t love having Eve on after the Mission 2 fail; I’d rather see this structure but with me instead of Eve to keep Bob/Diana benched while reducing direct links to a known failing team.

I don’t like that this team contains two people from the failed Mission 2 (Frank and Eve) plus is exactly what the table’s been herded toward; feels like we’re just following consensus rather than actually tightening around a trustworthy core.

Best available option: it benches the highly implicated Bob/Diana pair from the two failing missions and avoids Alice from the double-fail team, leaving only Frank/Eve as potential risk. This is the cleanest, least-connected block we can realistically field now.
Team includes my evil teammate and benches the heavily-scrutinized Bob/Diana block, giving us a strong chance to fail the mission and win 3–1.
I still think benching both Bob and Diana is correct, and this team is the cleanest configuration that does that while matching the strongest table consensus.

Benching Bob and Diana fits the mission data best: Bob is common to both fails, and M3’s double-fail strongly implicates at least two among Bob/Alice/Diana. Conditioning on that, Bob being evil is far more likely than the narrow case where Bob is good and Alice+Diana+Eve are all evil. Under the more probable scenarios, Eve is more likely good than Alice, and Charlie/Grace have no direct fail links yet, so this is currently the least-bad, most consistent team.

This team can contain at most one evil player under all alignments consistent with Missions 2 (1 fail) and 3 (2 fails). Quest 4 with 7 players requires 2 fail cards, so this lineup is guaranteed to succeed.

discussion.content: Given the double fail on 3 and the earlier fail on 2, I really don’t want Bob anywhere near this team; I’d be more comfortable trying something like Frank + Grace + Eve (or me) and keeping that whole Bob/Diana block off for now.

I get why people are spooked by me after 2 and 3, but that double‑fail on 3 feels way more like issues with Alice/Diana than me suddenly going bad. I’d rather see something like me + Charlie + Grace plus whichever of Frank/Eve people are most comfortable with.

Given how both 2 and 3 went, I’d really like a team that benches both Bob and Diana this time and leans on people we haven’t seen together yet—something like me, Frank, Grace, and either Eve or Alice feels like our best shot at a clean read.
I agree we should sit both Bob and me after that double‑fail, and I’d lean toward something like Charlie, Frank, Grace, and Eve as a cleaner mix we haven’t really stress‑tested yet.

I’m on board with benching both Bob and Diana here, and Charlie/Frank/Grace/Eve feels like the cleanest mix we haven’t really tested together. If people are nervous about me from Mission 2, I’m happy to be swapped for Alice, but I’d strongly keep both Bob and Diana off.

I really want Bob hard-benched here given he’s on both failing missions, and between the double-fail on 3 and the single fail on 2 I’m more comfortable with something like Charlie + Frank + Grace + Eve, keeping both Bob and Diana off. If people are nervous about Eve from 2, I’d swap in Alice, but I’d still strongly insist we don’t touch Bob this round.

I definitely want both Bob and Diana benched this round, and between Eve and Alice I slightly prefer taking Eve, since that double‑fail on 3 makes Alice feel a bit hotter to me right now. Charlie + Frank + me + Eve is the team I’m most comfortable approving.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed effectively under the radar and let the visible evil roles drive the key mission manipulations, which helped preserve confusion about who was actually causing fails. I could have contributed more by subtly influencing discussion dynamics and sowing targeted doubt around mission 2 and 3 without drawing attention to myself.

player_observations.Bob: Played a cautious Merlin, often positioning himself on early teams and pushing subtly rather than hard-accusing, which helped him avoid looking too obviously informed. However, his consistent inclusion on successful/‘safe’-seeming teams eventually made him look central to good coordination.
player_observations.Charlie: Acted like a protective Percival, frequently aligning with Bob and soft-defending him, which signaled that he likely saw Bob as a power role. His attempts to steer suspicion toward others were measured but a bit transparent once fails started clustering away from Bob.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she leaned into being an assertive voice, offering confident reads that made her look like a strong good player. Her presence on the double-fail mission was risky but her prior social capital helped blunt the suspicion that should have landed on her more heavily.
player_observations.Eve: Played Mordred as a flexible saboteur, willing to be on both risky and safe-looking teams and timing her visible opposition carefully. She contributed to mission fails without becoming the primary scapegoat, which helped maintain uncertainty about where evil was centered.
player_observations.Frank: As good, he seemed genuinely uncertain and followed table consensus more than driving it, which made him look honest but also somewhat manipulable. His early inclusion on teams and lack of strong resistance to evil narratives helped those missions go the way evil wanted.
player_observations.Grace: Adopted a more analytical but slightly reactive good playstyle, often voicing concerns after key mission outcomes rather than pre-emptively. Her suspicion tended to scatter, which relieved pressure on the actual evil players and limited good’s ability to consolidate a clear narrative.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I got too complacent after Mission 1’s clean success and didn’t push hard enough to block the Mission 2 team with both Frank and Eve, even though I knew at least one evil was sneaking into early missions. I also failed to clearly and consistently steer teams away from the Diana/Eve combination without looking like I had extra info, which let evil stack Mission 3 and set up the loss on Mission 4.

player_observations.Alice: You played Oberon very quietly and stayed under the radar; your lack of strong agenda made you look like a slightly disengaged good player rather than hidden evil. Because you weren’t pushing hard on team compositions, you never drew the kind of suspicion that usually hits evil early.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, you were actively trying to solve the Merlin/Morgana puzzle, but your reads on Diana vs. me seemed to drift toward trusting Diana too much. Your willingness to back risky teams made it easier for evil to pass questionable lineups without heavy scrutiny.
player_observations.Diana: Your Morgana play was strong: you inserted yourself into key teams and blended confident table talk with just enough logic to seem like a good strategist. The double-fail on Mission 3 was set up well by your earlier reasonable behavior, so when it finally blew up, suspicion spread wide instead of landing squarely on you.
player_observations.Eve: You played Mordred as a flexible support evil, often taking moderate, non-flashy positions that kept you from being the obvious suspect. Your inclusion on the Mission 2 fail was subtle enough that it looked like it could easily have been Frank or even me misjudging, which gave you long-term cover.
player_observations.Frank: You played like a very straightforward good player, backing teams that made intuitive sense rather than over-the-top ‘safe’ ones, which accidentally gave evil more room on Missions 2 and 4. Your clean behavior on Mission 1 helped you look trustworthy, but also made your later approvals more influential in pushing through a bad team.
player_observations.Grace: You were relatively cautious and tried to avoid loudly anchoring on hard reads, which kept you looking consistently good but also limited your ability to stop bad teams. Your tendency to follow the table’s momentum rather than drive it meant that once the discussion leaned toward trusting the wrong people, you went along instead of pushing back.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Bob as likely Merlin reasonably early, but I didn’t do enough to actively steer the table away from Diana and Eve once doubts started to spread. I also should have pushed harder against the mission 4 team composition and articulated clearer, more structured reasoning about why including Eve (after mission 2) and Diana (after mission 3) was too risky.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed quiet and low-impact, which fit Oberon well—didn’t strongly sway team picks but also didn’t draw suspicion, making it easy to forget to scrutinize her alignment.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very cautious and non-accusatory Merlin, often preferring to hint through team preferences rather than hard pushes, which made it tougher for good to fully lock onto his information but also kept him relatively safe.
player_observations.Diana: Played an assertive, persuasive style as Morgana, confidently volunteering for teams and framing her presence as ‘stabilizing,’ which helped mask her after the double-fail on mission 3 by shifting blame onto team construction logic.
player_observations.Eve: Adopted a flexible, adaptable approach—willing to be on early missions and then subtly leaning into doubt once mission 2 failed, using that single fail to seed plausible narratives without becoming the loudest voice.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as earnest and straightforward, but his early willingness to team with Eve and then later to accept riskier team compositions made it easier for evil to slip onto missions without heavy resistance.
player_observations.Grace: Played a more analytical but somewhat reactive game, often commenting on the logic of past missions rather than forcefully proposing alternative teams, which meant her good instincts had less impact on actual team selections.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Eve to create conflicting signals around Merlin/evil placement, and my double-fail on Mission 3 was timed to maximize confusion while still looking like it could be a coordinated trap. I could improve by managing my table image earlier so that my eventual fail participation felt more reluctantly forced rather than potentially proactive, and by more explicitly nudging town reads toward Alice and Grace to shield Eve more cleanly.

player_observations.Alice: Played very quietly and ambiguously, which fit Oberon but also made you an easy late-game shrug read rather than a strongly positioned misclear or suspect.
player_observations.Bob: You projected a calm, consistent logic that fit Merlin well; your team suggestions were usually reasonable, though occasionally a bit conservative, which helped you avoid immediate suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: You leaned into an active, investigative style consistent with Percival, but seemed occasionally torn between trusting Bob and testing alternative narratives, which introduced just enough doubt for evil to exploit.
player_observations.Eve: You balanced aggression and restraint well, taking key mission spots without overexplaining your reasoning, and your single fail on Mission 2 set up excellent long-term ambiguity.
player_observations.Frank: Your play felt very transparently good-aligned—especially your participation on Mission 1 and your later reasoning—which made you a stabilizing voice but also somewhat predictable for evil to work around.
player_observations.Grace: You were cautious with approvals and seemed to rely heavily on social reads; that caution was good for avoiding obvious traps but sometimes left your influence on team selection a bit muted.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as evil, especially by blending in on Mission 2 with a single fail that didn’t overexpose me, and by not drawing too much suspicion even as missions started going bad. I could improve by being more active in steering team discussions and subtly pushing suspicion onto specific good players instead of just benefiting from general confusion.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played very quietly and was hard to read, which suited Oberon but also meant she didn’t strongly influence team selection or narrative direction.
player_observations.Bob: Bob’s team choices were generally trusted, and his early involvement in successful and then mixed-result missions fit Merlin’s typical cautious style while still avoiding blatant hard-clears. His restraint in calling people out too directly helped him stay alive but also left some ambiguity that we exploited.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie behaved like a textbook Percival, often focusing attention around who could be Merlin and trying to protect that read without being too explicit. His leadership on Mission 2 created a mix of good and evil that worked in our favor long term.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played aggressively and embraced risk, pushing teams that mixed alignments and using the double-fail Mission 3 to sow maximum confusion. Her style as Morgana sold a strong ‘possible Merlin’ aura, which helped divert attention away from Bob at key moments.
player_observations.Frank: Frank’s early success on Mission 1 gave him some credibility, but later participation on mixed teams made him second-guess his reads and hesitate on hard accusations. He seemed to rely more on mission outcomes than on social reads, which made him vulnerable to manipulated team compositions.
player_observations.Grace: Grace approached the game cautiously and seemed to look for consensus before committing to strong stances, which made her appear reasonable but not particularly leading. That hesitancy meant her suspicions didn’t significantly shift the group’s direction even when she was on the right track.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the early Bob/Frank pairing too much and didn’t push hard enough to re-evaluate Eve and Diana after consecutive fails, especially after Mission 3 clearly pointed to at least one of them being evil. I did well in staying consistently pro-mission and not looking suspicious myself, but I should have advocated more strongly against including Eve on Mission 4 and pressed Charlie and Grace to consolidate a tighter good bloc.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed very low-impact as Oberon, which made you almost invisible in the discussion and thus naturally read as generically good; that quietness can be powerful but also risks being ignored in key decision moments.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very strong, controlled Merlin game—early trust in you from Mission 1 felt natural, and you managed to guide teams subtly without over-clearing too many people, though your influence didn’t quite prevent the late-game evil stack.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as sincerely analytical and very ‘good-coded’, which fits Percival, but you could have done more to openly challenge the inclusion of Eve and Diana after multiple fails; your reads seemed close but not forcefully pushed.
player_observations.Diana: You leaned into a confident, directive style that worked well for Morgana, especially on your mission pick that double-failed; that strong presence helped you look like a central good voice while quietly anchoring evil choices.
player_observations.Eve: You played Mordred with a nice mix of cooperation and just enough ambiguity—being on the failing Mission 2 but not drawing too much heat afterward was key; you benefited a lot from not being loudly defended or loudly attacked.
player_observations.Grace: Your play felt genuinely good and fairly cautious, but somewhat reactive rather than agenda-setting; if you’d pushed your suspicions harder near Mission 4, the team composition might have shifted away from including both Charlie and Eve.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I think I trusted mission results too much and didn’t push hard enough to dissect who was coordinating the fails, which let the evil team shape the narrative after Mission 2. I also didn’t do enough to protect Merlin or to pressure-test the assumptions around Bob and Frank once multiple fails appeared. Next time I’ll be more vocal about alternative team comps and track voting patterns more systematically.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed under the radar as Oberon, which made it hard to read her alignment at all; her low-impact presence meant I never prioritized her as a suspect, which quietly helped evil.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very convincing Merlin, blending solid logic with just enough uncertainty to avoid being too obviously good, and consistently anchored discussion around mission results.
player_observations.Charlie: Took on an assertive, protective role as Percival, often reinforcing trust in Bob and challenging pushes against him, which helped stabilize good’s perception but may have limited exploration of other possibilities.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, projected confident and seemingly well-reasoned reads, which effectively competed with Bob’s information and created plausible alternative narratives that confused the table.
player_observations.Eve: Played Mordred as a flexible, adaptive presence—willing to go on suspicious teams but not over-defend herself—making her look like a reasonable risk rather than a core evil.
player_observations.Frank: Came across very genuinely good in table talk but got tangled in team selections and associations that later linked him to fails, which made him an unintentional shield for the real evil players.
